p: Following the production of a fruiting stem, the green color of the stalk starts to turn into purplish-red, which is due to the senescent signaling of dying plant ( Figure 12). After the dispersion of mericarps, the fruiting stem dries and remains in its place for at least a year. Perhaps the remnant of the dead stalk was the source of Theophrastus’ statement about the longevity of the stem of the silphion plant: “The stalk lasts only a year, like that of Ferula”. Theophrastus also suggested that the leaf of silphion is “of a golden color” [ 9]. Although the leaves of F. drudeana are green, as is the case for the other extant Ferula species, in late summer before they become completely dry as the leaves start losing their chlorophyll and turn into a golden color as described by Theophrastus ( Figure 12).
